PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person preparing this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general question which would be applicable to pioneer life because no two persons who have lived in pioneer life have exactly the same experiences; others may have been more fortunate than others. Some of the questions here will apply to your experience; others may not. If there is anything about leaving blank spaces, please do not worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada between 1914 and 1945, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years either born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been printed or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires

- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneers in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
Pioneer Experiences

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada for more than one generation can answer all questions accurately. Some experiences may be common to many people; others may be unique to individuals or families.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They were very much surprised when I told them about my decision.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?
   I traveled with my husband, a short time after we were married.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   We came by the C.M.R. via Chicago, Minneapolis, and St. Paul.

14. What incidents of the journey most do you remember? (People you met on the way, interesting sights, adventures on the journey, accidents or other incidents, etc.)
   We came by train C.M.R. via Chicago, Minneapolis, and St. Paul. One incident was going from one station to another in Chicago, where we had a pleasant surprise when we turned a man and his wife who were on their way from England to Canada. The family was from London, England.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   The first night we stayed at the Arms Hotel.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? North half section 16, Township 89.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?
   I worked in a millinery store at that time.

20. Could you make a living with anything you could help me find?

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount? I can hardly wait! The way they used to travel! The day I arrived was the most memorable day of my life. We traveled by horseback through the wilderness. We didn't have any cars or trucks. We had to walk all the way. It was very difficult, but we made it. We arrived at our destination and were so happy to see each other again.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

Nearly every Sunday. We traveled six miles to our neighbors' house. We didn't own a car, so we walked everywhere. We attended the little Anglican church in our district each sunday, although we were attending presbyterian services. We rarely went to another church.

I could relate many things but will just mention one or two others. We were hungry for some pleasure so when my first boy was just a year old we heard of a dance 20 miles away. So we hitched our team to the sleigh put the baby buggy on the sleigh drove to a neighbor changed teams they went along. Went on further the second team was tired so this man went out to the straw stack caught a team and hitched to our sleigh took us the rest of the way at noon the next day when we got home but happy that we had met some new people neighbor 30 miles away. The next summer for over a week I walked one mile & a half everyday & wheeled my baby in his buggy to stay part of the day with a neighbor who was sick & could not get help.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

None before 1914

35. Did any move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Many families moved from our district but a great many returned immediately after the war. The majority moved to cities that had more work and better living conditions. The majority of those who left returned within five years.

36. If you or some members of your family have held public office or have been active in any organizations, mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

My husband was elected to the Board of Education in 1928 and then again in 1930. He served until 1934 when he was elected to the Board of Education again.

37. Things in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

The school building was built in 1910 and was dedicated in 1911.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School, district, town, etc.)

Post offices, villages, and corporations of persons suggesting place names.

39. Give meaning of the name(s) date of its origin, date and reason for change, give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Our school which was known as "Darby Glen" was named by a local lady Mrs. W. L. Davis. It was very close to a cotton field where a school was built and named "Darby Glen" after the young man who lived there. The school was closed in 1930 due to the depression.

40. Mention any other interesting facts about your district.
